lines.text: May I present my card?
'Novelties and Notions.' What kind of notions you got?
You'd be surprised. Some are old, some are new. Whom have I the honor of addressing, m'lady?
Mmm, they call me Flower Belle.
Flower Belle, what a euphonious appellation. Easy on the ears and a banquet for the eyes.
You're kinda cute yourself.
Thank you. I never argue with a lady.
Smart boy.
Mmm, funny, every man I meet wants to protect me. I can't figure out what from.
Uh, is this a game of chance?
Not the way *I* play it, no.
Sleep! The most beautiful experience in life. Except drink.
Any time you got nothin' to do and lots of time to do it, come up.
[the town mob is about to lynch Twillie]
I'd like to see Paris before I die... Philadelphia will do.
We was doin' arithmetic on the blackboard when Miss Foster took sick.
Oh, arithmetic... I was always pretty good at figures myself.
Are you trying to show *contempt* for this court?
No... I'm doin' my best to *hide* it!
Tell me, prairie flower, can you give me the inside info on yon damsel with the hothouse cognomen?
Do you mean Miss Flower Belle Lee?
I don't mean some woman out in China.
Well! I'm afraid I can't say anything good about her.
I can see what's good. Tell me the rest.
Big chief gottum new squaw?
"New" is right. She hasn't been unwrapped yet.
During one of my treks through Afghanistan, we lost our corkscrew. Compelled to live on food and water...
Will you play cards!
...for several days.
Squawk Mulligan tells me you buried your wife several years ago.
Ah, yes. I had to. She died.
If a thing is worth having, it's worth cheating for.
[giving schoolboys an arithmetic lesson]
Two and two is four and five will get you ten if you know how to work it.
Spring is the time for love.
What's the matter with the rest of the year?

[to Wayne Carter]
You're a man with ideals. Well, I guess I better be goin' while you still got 'em.

[reading off the blackboard]
"'I am a good boy. I am a good man. I am a good girl." What is this, propaganda?
...if you ask me...
Well nobody *asked* ya! So close yer gopher-trap, ya old snapping turtle!
You are the sheriff wife now. It would be very embarrassing for you to know who I am.
Mmm... I've never been embarrassed in my life.
I'm Jeff Badger. I own this place. Is there anything I can do for you?
Yeah, you can get outta my way.
I wonder what kind of a woman you really are.
Too bad, but I can't give out samples.
Ohhh! I hope that wasn't whiskey you were drinking.
Ah, no, dear, just a little sheep dip. Panacea for all stomach ailments.
Come, my phlox, my flower! I have some very definite pear-shaped ideas that I'd like to discuss with thee.
father, mother, husband, counselor, jackanapes, bartender...
You're offering quite a bundle, honey.
My heart is a bargain today. Will you take me?
[she sneaks a look at his satchel full of what she thinks is money]
I'll take you - and how.
And as for that tenderfoot sheriff, why, he couldn't keep his nose out of a bottle long enough to hold up a dog's tail, much less a stagecoach.
[last lines - each saying a line associated with the other]
If you get up around the Grampian Hills - You must come up and see me sometime.
Ah, yeah, yeah, I'll do that, my little chickadee.
I generally avoid temptation... unless I can't resist it.
Was that chap dragging you across the prairie a full-blooded Indian?
Ah, quite the antithesis. He's very anemic.
Babydoll, these weed-benders have been running off at the mouth... to your detriment.
Hmmm, I ain't surprised. Bad news travels fast.
I understand you need a Cicero and guide.
I need more than that, honey.
[she places her arm on the seat back between them - he takes her hand]
Ah, what symmetrical digits! Soft as the fuzz of a baby's arm.
But quick on the trigger.
Mmm, yes. Uh, may I?
[kisses her fingers]
Help yourself.
Would you object if I avail myself of a second helping?
Don't you think you're a little forward on such short acquaintance? You're compromising me.
[to the hotel porter]
flamingoes... wine wombats... Indian civets.
I've been worried about you, my little peachfuzz. Have you been loitering somewhere?
I've been learning things.
Unnecessary! You are the epitome of erudition... a double superlative. Can you handle it?
Yeah, and I can kick it around, too.

I'm tending bar one time down in the lower East side in New York... a tough felona comes in there by the name of Chicago Molly. I cautioned her, "None of your peccadilloes in here." There was some hot lunch on the bar comprising of succotash, Philadelphia cream cheese and asparagus with mayonnaise. She dips her mitt down into this melange - I'm yawning at the time - and she hits me right in the mug with it. I jumps over the bar and I knocks her down.

[walks up]
Where's the funnel?
I don't know. It's up along there somewhere. You were there the night I knocked Chicago Molly down, weren't you?
YOU knocked her down? I was the one that knocked her down.

[to the barfly]
Oh, yeah, yes, that's right. He knocked her down. But I was the one started kicking her!
Here's the funnel.

[to Squawk]
Yeah, OK.
[to barfly]
I starts kicking her in the midriff. D'ja ever kick a woman in the midriff that had a pair of corsets on?
No, I just can't recall any such incident right now.
Why I almost broke my great toe. I never had such a painful experience.
Uh, did she ever come back again?
I'll say she came back! She came back a week later and beat the both of us up.
Yeah. But she had another woman with her... an elderly lady with gray hair.
I never argue - with a lady.
Play it safe, huh?
I think you could turn a man's head very easily if he wasn't careful.
Well, there's no fun in being too careful.
Aren't you forgetting that you're married?
I'm doin' my best.
There's no such thing as law and order in this town. Decent citizens live in fear of their lives.
That ain't right. There should be a law against it.
These are right pretty pictures of you, Flower Belle.
Yeah, I like'em. They look just like me.
Don't mind being' held up, but I don't like the inconvenience.

[to goat in his bed]
Godfrey Daniel! Beelzebub! I've been hoodwinked. Shadrach and Abednego! The mystery of the fur coat. And I wanted to kiss you!
I was in a tight spot, but I managed to wiggle out of it.

[Outside the hotel]
Hmm... Must be Big Chief's new teepee.
Milton, my brave, go upstairs and park your stoical presence outside the teepee of Mrs. Twillie. Number 8. I'll proceed to the local gin mill, and absorb a beaker of firewater.
Big Chief gottum new squaw?
she hasn't been unwrapped yet.

[Loudly protesting his being forcibly thrown out of Jeff's bar for cheating at cards]
Unhand me! I'm an American citizen! Unhand me! I'm a taxpayer! I shall write the 'Times' about this. Call me a barrister! Unhand me! Unhand me, you uncouth larrikins! This is sabotage! A crime against liberty!

[Commenting on Jeff's bar, "The Last Gasp"]
Hmm, this reminds me of the "White Palace" in Chicago... only this ain't white.
Oh, you're from Chicago?
Yeah, every bit of me.
There's something sweet and dainty about a woman's boudoir.
How do *you* know?
Ah... huh? Huh?
Come on, answer the question.
Why, the latest etiquette books are just full of such knowledge!
Oh... for a second I thought I heard the voice of experience.
My boy, being sheriff of this town is pretty dangerous. The people here don't know the difference between the sheriff and a clay pigeon.

[Wearing a large, funny-looking nightgown]
Here I come, dear, ready or not! I feel rather parky, dear, in this diaphanous ubeitsehr.
'The Art of Arising the Morning After'.

[Commenting on Twillie's hangover]
Chief no feel good, huh?
I feel as though a midget with muddy feet had been walking over my tongue all night.

[Parting with Flower Belle]
Well, I have to hurry back east to attend to some oil wells I have there.

[Surprised]
Oil wells?
Yes, uh, 'hair oil' wells.

[Chuckles, rolls her eyes]
What a man!
